proposals.reasoning: This sticks with the idea I already floated: avoid stacking two strong agenda-setters right away and instead use a steady, low-drama pair for an initial read. Alice is a natural early anchor that most people are comfortable testing, and including myself lets us gather information without immediately tying up both core consensus voices (like Alice and Bob) on the very first mission. If this comes back clean, we have one trusted anchor plus me to compare against future teams that bring in Bob, Diana, or Eve.

votes.comment: Charlie is pushing to be on the first team, and most table sentiment leaned toward Alice+Bob as the low-drama test. Given Charlie’s past style and the lack of pressure to rush this, I’d rather not anchor early trust on him.

I’d rather not give Charlie a cleared-looking slot off the very first mission; I prefer starting with Alice plus someone who hasn’t pushed as hard to be on the initial team, like me or Eve, to keep early info more balanced.
I like being on the first mission to gather info and can keep it clean to build trust if needed.
Keeping Charlie on the team is good for us long-term, and rejecting the very first low-info proposal would be unnecessarily suspicious.
I preferred the more broadly supported Alice+Bob test; Alice overriding that to include Charlie and herself feels slightly agenda-driven this early.

proposals.reasoning: This pair has broad support from the table as a low-drama, low-information first test. Both have been willing to be checked early, neither is pushing too hard for control, and starting with them gives us a clean baseline result to build future teams around without concentrating too much influence or volatility on the very first mission.

votes.comment: Standard low-info first mission including me; good way to get an early read on Bob and establish a baseline.
This matches what I argued for earlier: a low-drama first test with Alice plus me gives a clean baseline and avoids stacking strong influencers or suspected wild cards.
This team has broad support and I’m fine starting with a low-drama, information-gathering pair off the first mission.
I already voiced support for Alice+Bob as a low-drama first test, so approving keeps my stance consistent and avoids drawing early suspicion.
Decent low-drama first test with broad support and no better alternative info-wise yet.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d prefer starting with a low-information, low-risk pair—maybe me plus someone who isn’t pushing too hard to be on the first mission. I’m also wary of letting the same confident voices always set the early teams, so I’d like to see a balanced mix of quieter and more vocal players as we go.

For the first 2-person team, I’m fine keeping it simple with you plus someone who hasn’t been angling too hard for influence yet—maybe me or Eve, just to spread early info a bit. I’d avoid stacking early leadership and loud voices together until we see more.

I’d rather not put both a vocal leader and a potential wild card together right away, so I’m good with Alice plus me for a steady first read, and we can bring in the stronger personalities once we’ve seen at least one mission result.

I’d rather start with a pair that isn’t already trying to shape the table too much, so Alice plus Bob feels like a solid, low-drama first test to me. If that comes back clean, we’ve got a stable core to build from.

I’m okay starting with Alice plus Bob as a low-drama test, since both seem comfortable being checked early. I’d rather keep the first mission simple and then use that result to decide whether to bring in Charlie or me next.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s clean success with Alice and Bob gives us the best available core, but one success doesn’t clear either of them, especially since an evil player might allow the first mission to pass. Adding myself keeps the original leader (Diana) and the most eager volunteer (Charlie) off this mission, which isolates the variable to a single new player and gives us a clearer read: if this team fails, suspicion is concentrated on me vs. one of Alice/Bob; if it succeeds, we gain confidence in all three without prematurely locking in Diana or Charlie as trusted. This is the most information-rich, low-variance test for Mission 2.

votes.comment: Keeps the successful Alice–Bob core and adds just one new variable (Eve), giving strong info either way without involving both untested players at once.
Mission 1’s Alice/Bob core is our best info so far, and adding a single new player for an isolated test is a solid way to get more clarity early.

Keeping both known non-leader candidates (Charlie and Diana) off again narrows future clears too much; I’d prefer a mix that includes at least one of them so we don’t over-trust this trio off just two missions.
This matches the earlier consensus I supported to keep Alice/Bob together and test Eve while leaving me and Charlie off for a cleaner read.
Standard info-rich extension of the clean M1 core, and I’m on it; good chance it’s mostly/entirely good and gives strong data either way.

discussion.content: Mission 1 going well with me and Bob is a decent early sign, so I’d lean toward keeping us together, but I don’t think that alone clears either of us—whoever leads should add one new person and we see how that mix behaves.

Sticking with Alice and me feels like our safest core for now, and I’d lean toward adding Eve next so we’re not immediately re-using the Mission 1 leader. Keeping Charlie and Diana off this one gives us a cleaner read on a mostly-new mix.

I like keeping Alice and Bob together for now since that first mission was clean, and I’d rather add either me or Eve than reuse the original leader so we’re not just locking Diana in as trusted too quickly. If I’m on, I’m fine being “tested” here so we get more info from the result.

I’m good keeping Alice and Bob together after a clean first mission, and between Eve and Charlie I’d slightly rather test Eve here since Charlie’s been pretty eager to jump on. That gives us new info without immediately rewarding the most vocal volunteer.

I’m fine with keeping Alice and Bob together after a clean first mission, but I don’t want to auto-clear them off just one success, so I like the idea of adding me as the third while we keep Charlie and Diana off for a more focused read.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and Bob have been on both previous missions, which each succeeded with 0 FAIL cards. With a 2–0 lead, the highest-percentage play for good is to reuse the most trusted pair rather than introduce new risk just for information. If either Alice or Bob were evil, they would have already passed up two prime chances to sabotage; while possible, that is strategically unlikely, especially with the game on the line. Choosing this team maximizes the chance of securing the third successful mission and ending the quest phase in good’s favor, without needlessly exposing new players or giving evil extra opportunities.

votes.comment: With two clean missions using this same core pair, repeating Alice+Bob is the highest-probability path to a third success and avoids introducing new, unnecessary risk.
Same proven-good pair from the first two clean missions; with a 2–0 lead, this is the safest path to securing the third success.
If Alice–Bob is actually 2 good, this auto-hands good the game; we need a different combo to avoid locking in a clean third success.

If Alice–Bob is hiding a deep-cover evil, repeating them ends the game with no way to ever test that. With 2–0 already, I’d rather see at least one new person on the team to generate information instead of auto-locking the same pair again.
Two clean missions with the same core strongly suggest Alice and Bob are good; at 2–0 up, reusing the proven pair is the highest-percentage way to secure the win.

discussion.content: Given the first two clean missions, I strongly prefer we keep it simple and run Alice + Bob again here—no need to introduce new risk when this pair has a perfect record so far.

Sticking with Alice + me makes the most sense here—two clean missions with the same core is about as strong a signal as we’re going to get this early. If one of us were evil, odds are we’d have seen a fail by now, so I’m happy to rerun that pair.

I get that Alice–Bob looks safe, but if one of them is a deep-cover evil we’re basically handing over the game, so I’d rather see something like Alice–Charlie or Bob–Charlie to at least diversify the info we get. Repeating the exact same core three missions in a row feels like we’re flying blind.

I see the appeal of rerunning Alice + Bob, but if that pair is secretly harboring 1 evil we never get a chance to catch it—I'd rather keep Alice (since she’s been on both successes) and pair her with someone new like Charlie to at least generate fresh info.

Given two clean missions with the same core, I’m inclined to stick with Alice + Bob here and force evil to either keep giving us successes or finally reveal themselves. If this somehow fails, we’ll have a very clear place to focus suspicion afterward.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Bob as Merlin: he was the first one to explicitly say “keep Charlie and Diana off” in Mission 2, which is a bold double-read that happened to perfectly dodge both evils while still sounding like generic “info-gathering” talk. Eve echoed that logic but in a more follow-y, consensus way, and Alice felt more like a conservative, trust-the-proven-core leader than someone with sharp, targeted reads, so Bob’s the one whose “safe core” arguments consistently and precisely avoided us.

I’m mostly with Charlie on Bob being Merlin: he’s the one who very cleanly framed “keep Charlie and Diana off” in Mission 2 as a pure info play, which is a pretty gutsy double-hit on both evils that still sounded super reasonable. Alice reads more like a risk-averse core-builder who just kept rewarding what worked, and Eve’s arguments generally trailed Bob’s logic rather than driving it, so Bob feels like the player with the most *targeted* accuracy rather than generic caution.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Bob was the first to explicitly frame keeping both Charlie and Diana off Mission 2 as a clean ‘info-gathering’ move, which is an unusually accurate double-avoidance of the actual evils that still sounded generically reasonable. Across the discussions, he consistently pushed for the Alice–Bob core while subtly steering teams away from us with confident, targeted logic, whereas Alice seemed more risk-averse and Eve more follow-y than insight-driving, making Bob the most likely Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on missions and helped secure three clean successes, which was good for building a solid core of apparent goods. However, I didn’t push hard enough to question why missions were so safe or protect Merlin in the endgame, and I could improve at thinking from evil’s perspective to anticipate the assassination.

player_observations.Bob: Played very cleanly as Merlin, guiding teams toward perfect mission compositions without drawing too much suspicion, though the pattern of consistently correct team selections eventually gave evil enough information to make a strong assassination guess.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed good read accuracy as the assassin, paying close attention to who was driving the successful team choices and using that to pick out Merlin correctly at the end.
player_observations.Diana: Managed to stay under the radar as evil despite the string of successful missions, blending in well enough that her alignment wasn’t clearly questioned or pressed during the game.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a straightforward good player, supporting successful missions and not overcomplicating team discussions, which helped maintain trust but may have made it harder to challenge hidden evil influences.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed too clean and helpful on missions, which made my role as Merlin obvious once all three missions succeeded without any FAILs. I should have cast a bit more doubt or allowed some ambiguity about my reads instead of consistently supporting the safest good-only teams. In future games, I need to balance giving good teams enough info to win missions with leaving plausible deniability for the assassination phase.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared trustworthy and played in a straightforward, good-aligned manner, which made it easy for me to back teams including her. She didn’t push overly hard on any narrative, which helped her avoid suspicion and made her a safe anchor for mission teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Read the game well enough to land the correct assassination on me despite the missions all succeeding, suggesting careful attention to who was steering team selection and table talk. Likely keyed in on my pattern of reliably supporting strong good teams without much visible uncertainty.
player_observations.Diana: As evil, she played a very subtle game by proposing a fully good team on Mission 1, which bought her a lot of credibility without risking a fail. This low-profile, low-disruption approach let evil win through assassination instead of mission sabotage, which was very effective here.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a cautious, solid good player, willing to go on teams and contribute to success without drawing too much attention. Her alignment was not obviously broadcast, which helped keep the focus off her and on the more vocal or central decision-makers.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed under the radar effectively as Assassin and paid close attention to who was subtly steering team selections, which let me correctly identify Bob as Merlin despite all missions succeeding. I could improve by more actively shaping team discussions and sowing slightly more targeted doubt earlier, to create multiple plausible Merlin candidates and make the final guess even less risky.

player_observations.Alice: Seemed consistently trusted and got onto every mission, which suggests she projects a very 'safe' table image; her willingness to repeat similar team cores made it easier for Merlin to hide behind her apparent reliability.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled, low-drama Merlin: no hard pushes, but quietly supported strong good-team compositions and avoided over-defending anyone, which made the subtle alignment between his voting pattern and good outcomes a key Merlin tell.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as evil by never needing to fail missions and instead leaning on social trust and mission success; her restraint made the game feel very low-suspicion and kept attention away from hunting for evil.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as genuinely good but not strongly directive, often following consensus rather than driving it; this slightly passive style made her an unlikely Merlin candidate and helped narrow down endgame guesses.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-impact and non-controversial as an evil player, which helped missions pass cleanly and kept suspicion away from me while still enabling the assassin to get valuable info. I could improve by more actively shaping discussion to sow subtle doubt around non-Merlin good players, giving the assassin an even clearer picture without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and seemed comfortable approving and being on early teams, which made her look reliably good but also a bit easier to read since there wasn’t much misdirection.
player_observations.Bob: Gave off quiet, competent vibes and guided team selections in a way that felt ‘just logical enough,’ which fit a classic low-key Merlin style that still ended up being detectable.
player_observations.Charlie: Patient as assassin and didn’t force chaos; instead, relied on inference from clean missions and subtle behavioral cues, which suggests a preference for calculated, information-based assassinations.
player_observations.Eve: Trusted early mission structures and didn’t push hard against the emerging consensus, signaling a more cooperative, consensus-driven style that’s great for team harmony but can make it harder to disrupt evil’s information-gathering.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped build trust by supporting successful teams, which made me look reliably good-aligned. However, I didn’t push hard enough on deductions about who might be Merlin, nor did I challenge or test players’ reads in a way that could have better protected Merlin from being so clearly identified.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a very steady, trustworthy way, joining only successful missions and not drawing much suspicion. Her low-key style made her look solidly good without over-directing the table.
player_observations.Bob: His choices and confidence around team selections were subtly guiding the game, which in hindsight made him stand out as someone with extra information. The way he consistently aligned with successful teams without much visible doubt likely contributed to the assassin correctly identifying him as Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to stay completely under the radar despite being the assassin, likely by not overtly steering discussion and instead letting the good players implicate themselves through their own patterns. Their final assassin pick suggests they were carefully tracking who seemed too accurate or comfortable with team compositions.
player_observations.Diana: Led the first mission in a way that built early trust, especially by putting together a team that ended up succeeding and set a pro-good tone. As an evil player, she benefited from that early credibility and didn’t need to take big visible risks later in the game.
